Luigi Barzini, the Italian author and journalist, died Friday of cancer at his home in Rome, his family announced today. He was 75 years old.

A ceremony in memory of Mr. Barzini is scheduled to be held in Rome on Monday, after which his body will be buried in a family plot in Orvieto.

President Sandro Pertini and Prime Minister Bettino Craxi headed a list of public figures who sent condolences.

A Renaissance Man

Luigi Barzini, an Italian-born, American-educated author, journalist and member of the Italian Parliament, was something of a latter-day Renaissance man.

An urbane, witty intellectual who covered political upheavals and wars in Germany, Ethiopia and China, Mr. Barzini had a long and distinguished career. In his youth, he at first embraced Mussolini's Fascism, but was soon disillusioned and was eventually imprisoned for his opposition to the regime.

His best-known book, ''The Italians,'' cemented his reputation as a leading authority on the history, culture and national character of the Italian people. Although it amused, delighted and enlightened millions of foreigners, many of Mr. Barzini's fellow Italians were offended by its often stinging criticism.
